title: 109_s1862
content:
The Act may be cited as the "United States-Israel Energy Cooperation Act". Congress recognizes the importance of developing renewable energy sources for national security, acknowledges Israel as a strong ally, and highlights the successful scientific collaborations between the United States and Israel in various fields such as life sciences, medicine, and technology through programs like the BSF and BIRD. On February 1, 1996, the Secretary of Energy and the Israeli Minister of Energy signed an agreement for collaboration in energy research and development. Israeli scientists excel in alternative renewable energy sources, and increased cooperation between the US and Israel in this field would benefit both countries. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) BIRD - United States-Israel Binational Industrial Research and Development Foundation.
(2) BSF - United States-Israel Binational Science Foundation.
(3) Secretary - Secretary of Energy, through the Assistant Secretary for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy.

SEC. 4. GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary shall establish a grant program to support research, development, and commercialization of alternative renewable energy sources, including solar, biomass, energy efficiency, wind, fossil, and other types of energy as determined by the Secretary. Eligible applicants must address requirements in alternative energy areas to receive a grant. The Secretary establishes a grant program for research and development of alternative renewable energy sources. Eligible applicants must meet specific requirements and qualifications determined by the Secretary. To be eligible for a grant under this section, applicants must submit an application to the Secretary or the BIRD/BSF. The Secretary must allocate at least 50% of funds for grants through the BIRD and BSF. The Secretary establishes an advisory board to monitor grant awards and provide performance reviews. The board includes representatives from the US and Israel. Recipients of grants may be required to repay them. The Secretary may require grant recipients to repay the grant amount plus interest and administrative charges, not exceeding 150% of the grant amount. $20,000,000 is authorized for this section annually from 2006 to 2012.
